data.title: The 60 best love songs of all time
data.meta_description: Looking for the courage to confess your unrequited love, or just in need of a big old cry? We've got you.
data.text:
Thereâ€™s nothing quite so compelling, heart-wrenching or soul-shaking as a really top notch love song. The best can conjure up a euphoric urge for you to belt along, or reduce you to a sad, quivering, emotional wreck.

But the genre is, as we know, an incredibly saturated market, and weâ€™ve been writing love songs since the Dark Ages after all. Donâ€™t stress your little heart out too much, though, as weâ€™ve put in the legwork to bring you this roundup of the very best lovey-dovey tunes, from a 1950s hit by The Flamingos to the dulcet tones of BeyoncÃ©.

RECOMMENDED:

ğŸ†The sexiest songs of all time

ğŸ’‹The best R&B love songs

ğŸ’”The best breakup songs

ğŸºThe best soul songs

This guide was recently updated by NYC-based arts and culture journalist Alessandra Schade. Entries are by Time Out Editors. For more about how we curate, have a look at our editorial guidelines.

1. â€˜At Lastâ€™ by Etta James

The most unapologetically romantic slow-danceâ€“weddingâ€“love-scene song in history, Etta Jamesâ€™s 1960 cover of â€˜At Lastâ€™ may seem a bit clichÃ©. But from the first note, we all know whatâ€™s coming (love! finally!), and Jamesâ€™s soulful crooning induces a shiver every time, whether we expect it to or not. Case in point, pretty much everyone lost it during BeyoncÃ©â€™s rendition at the 2009 presidential inauguration ball for Obama including the First Lady and President himself. Cuuute.

2. â€˜All of Meâ€™ by John Legend

For a decade now, â€˜All of Meâ€™ has been the veritable go-to wedding song across the globe. And for good reason. â€˜All of Meâ€™ is a dedication to Legendâ€™s then fiancee, now wife, Chrissy Teigen, and serves as a love letter to significant otherâ€™s everywhere. The earnest piano ballad, boasting the moving lyrics, â€˜Love your curves and all your edges/ all your perfect imperfectionsâ€™ has made this love song one of the greatest of our generation. And the stats come to support that. According to Spotify, â€˜All of Meâ€™ is the most-added song in userâ€™s â€˜loveâ€™ themed playlists for lovers of the streaming generation.

Alessandra Schade

Contributing Writer, Music

Advertising

3. â€˜Letâ€™s Stay Togetherâ€™ by Al Green

The lyrics to the Reverendâ€™s landmark 1971 love song, â€˜Letâ€™s Stay Togetherâ€™ articulate the solemn vows of marriage: â€˜Whether times are good or bad, happy or sad.â€™ But sung by Green, these promises are given wings. Covered multiple times since its release, Greenâ€™s gorgeous original was given a new lease on life in â€™94, when Quentin Tarantino featured it in Pulp Fiction. But our favorite boost for the song has to be when it was sung by Barack Obama at a fund-raising event in 2012.

4. â€˜All Nightâ€™ by BeyoncÃ©

When BeyoncÃ©â€™s hour-long visual album Lemonade hit the internet in 2016, the entire nation explored the intense range of emotions of marital infidelity: betrayal, jealousy, rage, and revenge. â€˜All Night,â€™ which wraps up the 12-track masterpiece (and is reportedly BeyoncÃ©â€™s favorite song from the record), brought something different to the table. Perhaps less sexy than the hell-hath-no-fury revenge tracks on the project, the powerful love ballad gave us a tender and compassionate ode to healing heartbreak and moving on. And what is more moving than selfless love? â€˜All Night,â€™ with its soulful vocals and haunting guitar, will forever encapsulate the seldom-explored topic of reconciliation and preservation in long-term commitments.

Alessandra Schade

Contributing Writer, Music

Advertising

5. â€˜Nothing Compares 2 Uâ€™ by SinÃ©ad Oâ€™Connor

While originally penned by Prince, â€˜Nothing Compares 2 Uâ€™ became SinÃ©ad Oâ€™Connorâ€™s most iconic song, with its haunting sound remaining as an enduring symbol of the â€˜90s. As is the case with other seminal love songs, it's often the delivery of a songâ€™s lyrics that make the track timeless. The Irish singerâ€™s ethereal vocals and raw intensity ignite the song with heartbreak. Oâ€™Connorâ€™s rendition of Princeâ€™s song is a stirring moment of emotional catharsis, a performance that draws from trauma and vulnerability, and portrays a type of pain that will tremble even the stiffest of upper lips.

Alessandra Schade

Contributing Writer, Music

6. â€˜Somethingâ€™ by the Beatles

â€˜Somethingâ€™ was the first George Harrison-written song to occupy the A-side of a Beatles single (though it did share the accolade, appearing as a double A-side with unifying call â€˜Come Togetherâ€™ in 1969). Capturing the swirling triumph of infatuation, the tune would become the second-most-covered song of the Beatlesâ€™ canon (â€˜Yesterdayâ€™ is the first). More than 150 artists have tried the dreamy, swooning ode on for size, including James Brown, Elvis Presley, Phish, Isaac Hayes and Frank Sinatra, who famously christened it the â€˜greatest love song ever written.â€™

Advertising

7. â€˜God Only Knowsâ€™ by the Beach Boys

In 1963, Brian Wilson was so obsessed with Phil Spectorâ€™s orchestral vision for the Ronettesâ€™ â€˜Be My Babyâ€™ that he reportedly took to listening to it 100 times a day. Three years later, Wilson and the Boys would surpass the master with a song that lifted the notion of the sophisticated love song clean into the heavens. The uncertainty of the first line (â€˜I may not always love youâ€™) is a classic pop curveball, which works with the swooping transition from intro to verse. Once that miasmic mix of harpsichords and celestial brass clears, and that opening caveat is laid bare, weâ€™re left with a heartbreakingly tender song of yearning, of devotion and of fidelity. The songâ€™s universality has turned it into an almost nondenominational and humanist hymn, blessed with an equivocal outlook that can magically give succor to all forms of love.

8. â€˜I Will Always Love Youâ€™ by Dolly Parton

Dolly Partonâ€™s farewell to her long-time partner and mentor, country legend Porter Wagoner, when she decided to pursue a solo career, became quite the sensation in 1974. Itâ€™s hard to think of a better song in pop culture that captures the â€˜if you love something, set it freeâ€™ sentiment. While few of usâ€”save Whitney Houstonâ€”can belt those high notes like Parton, that doesnâ€™t stop us from wanting to sing along with the chorus, with all the same pent up passion.

Advertising

9. â€˜My Girlâ€™ by the Temptations

This sugary â€™64 chart-topper (the Temptationsâ€™ first) might be the best puppy-love song ever. Penned by fellow Motown signees the Miracles, its instantly recognizable guitar riff (right up there with the one from â€˜Satisfactionâ€™), peppy finger snaps, unabashed optimism and comforting-as-a-much-needed-hug harmonies can make even the most jaded downer feel all warm inside.

10. â€˜Someone Like Youâ€™ by Adele

Written from the perspective of a woman who shows up at her exâ€™s front door only to discover that heâ€™s married and has moved on, â€˜Someone Like Youâ€™ is the ultimate ode to former lovers. The heartbreaking chorusâ€™ confused sentiment resonates with anyone who has ever tried to move on from their old flame, but is struggling. Adeleâ€™s passionate vocals and ambivalence to moving on gives color to the fantasy of going back to the one who got away and telling them: â€˜Babe, it ainâ€™t over for me, I havenâ€™t moved on, I never will.â€™ What is more powerful than unrequited love? Adele will answer this question for you.

Alessandra Schade

Contributing Writer, Music

Advertising

11. â€˜Helloâ€™ by Lionel Richie

Banish from your mindâ€™s eye the meltingly cheesy and vaguely creepy video for Lionel Richieâ€™s 1984 No. 1 hit, with its plot about a teacher, a blind girl and the clay bust she molds of him. But give yourself over to the softer kitsch of the love song itselfâ€”the slow build of anticipation, the rise and fall of the guitar solo, Richieâ€™s tender vocals as he imagines spilling his heart outâ€”and you may be surprised to find how well it has held up in the years since that rather unfortunate introduction.

12. â€˜Wonderful Worldâ€™ by Sam Cooke

If thereâ€™s anyone out there whose heart doesnâ€™t melt just a little bit when they hear the drum flutter that opens this 1960 swoon of a song, weâ€™ll eat our hat. â€˜Wonderful Worldâ€™ is lullaby-simple in its structureâ€”of course one and one is two! Of course this one should be with you!â€”echoing the way that when love feels right, itâ€™s somewhere between a no-brainer and a miracle. And no, we still donâ€™t know what a slide rule is for.

Advertising

13. â€˜Mapsâ€™ by Yeah Yeah Yeahs

While the lyrics to this early aughts classic are fairly repetitive, they become almost like a mantra. â€˜Wait, they donâ€™t love you like I doâ€™ is a thought perhaps way too many of us have had, whether spoken or not, as things start to fall apart in a relationship.

14. â€˜When a Man Loves a Womanâ€™ by Percy Sledge

Percy Sledgeâ€™s R&B (and wedding-soundtrack) staple might be one of the most romantic-sounding songs of all time, but the 1966 hitâ€™s lyrics basically boil down to this: Love fucks everything upâ€”your judgment, your pride, your friendships, your bank account, the roof over your head. It can be a powerful, fickle jerk, in other words. Oh, also: When youâ€™re under its spell, itâ€™s the absolute greatest thing in the world.

Advertising

15. â€˜Nothing Even Mattersâ€™ by Lauryn Hill

â€˜Nothing Even Mattersâ€™ might not have received as much recognition on Hillâ€™s critically acclaimed The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill as other singles, but, looking back, it was a near perfect showcase for two of the â€™90s foremost neo-soul artists. For two singers who reached the peaks of musical achievement through astounding ambition and innovation, this restrained and simple love song shows just how talented each was beneath it all. Hill and Dâ€™Angelo trade sensual verses with a smooth, tenderness in a stripped down ballad that might just make you want to strip down as well.

16. â€˜Thatâ€™s How Strong My Love Isâ€™ by Otis Redding

Otis, you slay us. Weâ€™re hard-pressed to think of an artist who croons the good, bad and ugly of love as heartbreakingly well, and this 1965 cover (of O.V. Wrightâ€™s â€™64 original) is no exception. The lyrics are so comforting, so reassuringâ€”especially when sung with Reddingâ€™s signature soulâ€”that it makes us feel adored just to hear them on the stereo.

Advertising

17. â€˜I Say a Little Prayerâ€™ by Aretha Franklin

Set in F minor, the song hits like a breakup. Burt Bacharach, you clever devil. Aretha belts it like tragedy, too. Thatâ€™s what puts it in the upper league, what separates it from the puppy-dog bullshit. Love is devastating. She turns her mundane morning ritualâ€”hair, makeup, dressingâ€”into opera.

18. â€˜Running Up That Hillâ€™ by Kate Bush

Not every love song has to be sexy! There are far friskier songs in Kate Bushâ€™s later work, but her 1985 smash remains one of the greatest and strangest love songs of all time. Over that unmistakable electronic drum figure, synths that swoop like alien birds and Bushâ€™s keening vocals work so harmoniously together that the song works more impressionistically than literally. But the â€˜dealâ€™ she describes is love, an annihilation of the self as she dreams of literally becoming the object of her affections so that she can better understand them.

Advertising

19. â€˜Everywhereâ€™ by Fleetwood Mac

Oh, you thought chillwave was some blogger invention of 2009? Take a dip in Fleetwood Macâ€™s â€˜Tango in the Nightâ€™ album, on which Buckingham, Nicks and McVie inventedâ€”no, perfectedâ€”the sound in 1987. On standout track â€˜Everywhereâ€™, McVie stacks and stacks her blissful sighs atop darting, shimmering Buckingham arpeggios and a breezy drum gallop. Eat your heart out, Beach House.

20. â€˜Vision of Loveâ€™ by Mariah Carey

Any number of Mariah Carey songs could claim a place on this list, but her stunning debut single remains irresistibly romantic. Released in 1990, itâ€™s a gorgeous, gospel-tinged pop-soul ballad that builds towards a thrilling climax featuring Mimiâ€™s signature whistle notes. Carey would go on to write and perform more sophisticated love songs, but â€˜Vision of Loveâ€™ captures that butterflies-in-your-stomach feeling with a giddy sense of bliss.

Advertising

21. â€˜Unchained Melodyâ€™ by the Righteous Brothers

Itâ€™s the mushy definition of a love song that becomes all the more powerful for it. â€˜Unchained Melodyâ€™ has all the corny trappings of a by-the-numbers ballad: the swooning, arpeggiated opening, the crescendo to an epic orchestral finale, lyrics whose blatant emotional manipulation ought to fall right apart under scrutiny. But thereâ€™s real, undeniable hunger in Bobby Hatfield's luminous and raw vocal, the push and pull of the instrumentation is subtler than expected, and the words reveal layers where true fidelity fights to overcome lingering doubt. The world seems to agree: The Righteous Brothersâ€™ version of the song remains the most popular and well-loved out of hundreds of recordings from around the globe.

22. â€˜Thinkin Bout Youâ€™ by Frank Ocean

â€˜Thinkin Bout You,â€™ the iconic song about an all-consuming crush, is more than just a potent love song that flexes gorgeous vocals and soaring instrumentalism. By using elements of various queer canonical events and allusions, the cheeky R&B track opened a conversation on Black queer artistry in the music industry, particularly in the hip-hip genre, which was still struggling with homophobia and toxic masculinity. The entire song represents the curiosity and uncertainty of sexual exploration and self-discovery, showing a generation of kids that listened to Channel Orange on repeat in their bedrooms, that love is for everyone.

Alessandra Schade

Contributing Writer, Music

Advertising

23. â€˜My Baby Just Cares for Meâ€™ by Nina Simone

Though Nina Simone recorded her definitive version of this standard in 1958, it became an unlikely chart hit in the U.K. nearly 30 years later, when it was used in a popular ad for perfume. The irony of this commercial connection is keen, since the song itself represents a rejection of material and cultural distractions. Simoneâ€™s account, though relatively lighthearted by her standards, nonetheless strips the ditty of much of its surface frivolity; in performance, her rendition could seem positively dour. With matter-of-fact majesty, she restores the love song, in a sense, to its own values.

24. â€˜I'm On Fireâ€™ by Bruce Springsteen

Bruce Springsteenâ€™s vast repertoire of poetic, politicised blue collar anthems leaves surprisingly little room for romance. But there is, of course, one great romantic jam in Broooceâ€™s ouvre. Over sultry layers of synth and a heartbeat drum machine, the narrator of â€˜Iâ€™m On Fireâ€™ is consumed with an almost unbearable desire. â€˜Hey little girl is your daddy home, did he go and leave you all alone?â€™ he coos and thereâ€™s an ambivalence to it: are his lyrics simply in the idiom of â€˜50s rockâ€™nâ€™roll? Or is there something forbidden about the characterâ€™s desires? The video strongly suggests the former, but thereâ€™s an undeniable element of danger to his love â€“ nay, obsession.

Advertising

25. â€˜I Want to Break Freeâ€™ by Queen

Though more often recognized as a song about breaking free from oppressionâ€”and for its amazing music video starring members of the band in dragâ€”thereâ€™s an undeniable love story also included here. The narrator has â€˜fallen in love for the first timeâ€™ and they know â€˜this time itâ€™s for real.â€™ How that love will blossom as that person finds their freedom to make it on their own is unclear, but hey, itâ€™s a start.

26. â€˜Friday Iâ€™m In Loveâ€™ by the Cure

While we actually enjoy getting super-sentimental to Robert Smithâ€™s voiceâ€”and typically canâ€™t stand to listen to so-called â€˜happy musicâ€™â€”this love songâ€™s catchy-as-hell hook and upbeat tempo serve as a good counterpoint to all those other straight-up tear-inducing Cure tunes. Plus, who doesnâ€™t love Friday?

Advertising

27. â€˜Sea of Loveâ€™ by Cat Power

Just how many times did this song appear on mix CDs made for dorm-room crushes in the aughts? Weâ€™re too busy to do the math, but weâ€™re guessingâ€¦a lot. Cat Powerâ€™s bare bones take on Phil Phillipsâ€™s classic, like many of the tracks on her 2000 LP â€˜The Covers Recordâ€™, imbues the much-loved song with a dose of longing and vulnerability.

28. â€˜Ainâ€™t Nobodyâ€™ by Rufus & Chaka Khan

Quincy Jones almost nabbed this slice of loved-up electrofunk for Michael Jackson, but it ended up becoming a signature tune for R&B diva Khan when she sang it with her old band Rufus in 1983. When Frankie Knuckles gave it a piano house remix in 1989, a new generation went crazy for the song: now artists ranging from Mary J. Blige to KT Tunstall have recorded versions, but none of them reach the thrilling heights of Chaka as she hits the final chorus.

Advertising

29. â€˜This Magic Momentâ€™ by the Drifters

Of course, number one has to be an old school tune. They knew romance back in the day, didnâ€™t they? And the 50s? Oh, that era was romantic. And this absolute tune by The Drifters, with the sweet sounds of Ben. E King on lead vocals, is a seriously romantic song. Gentle swirling strings carry you through the lyrics, â€˜Sweeter than wine / Softer than the summer night / Everything I want I have / Whenever I hold you tight.â€™ Weâ€™re not crying, youâ€™re crying. Unashamedly soppy, this is a masterpiece of the lurrrve genre.

30. â€˜Signed, Sealed, Delivered Iâ€™m Yoursâ€™ by Stevie Wonder

Stevie Wonder was a mere 20 years old when he released his apologetic anthem â€˜Signed, Sealed, Delivered Iâ€™m Yours.â€™ Even at that tender age, the Detroit prodigy had done a lot of foolish things that he really didnâ€™t mean, but making that record wasnâ€™t one of them: It spent six weeks atop the U.S. R&B chart and garnered Wonder his first Grammy nomination.

Advertising

31. â€˜Bound 2â€™ by Kanye West

Donâ€™t be turned off by the over-stylized video or the lyric â€˜Step back, canâ€™t get spunk on the minkâ€™â€”in our opinion, Kanyeâ€™s tribute to Kim Kardashian is one of the most heartwarming love songs of the past decade. Brilliantly honest and plainspoken (â€˜Okay, I donâ€™t remember where we first metâ€™), it rejects romantic clichÃ©s to paint an intimate picture of Ye and Kimâ€™s relationship. It may be over now, but hey, weâ€™ll always have the memories.

32. â€˜You Got Meâ€™ by the Roots

Fidelity is the name of the game in this 1999 Grammy-winning track from Phillyâ€™s favorite hip-hop sons, the Roots. A globe-trotting musician and a film student meet cute, but what happens when he goes back on tour and she starts drawing the attention of famous athletes? The dreaded long-distance relationship has been known to decimate many a couple, but not this time. Our steadfast heroineâ€”whose rhymes are courtesy of Ruff Ryders First Lady Eve and singing is by Erykah Baduâ€”assures her boo that his paranoia is unfounded and, no matter what, â€˜You got me.â€™ Sounds like a keeper!

Advertising

33. â€˜Be My Babyâ€™ by the Ronettes

Lennon covered it, Scorsese used it to announce his directorial arrival in Mean Streets, and, as discussed, Brian Wilson was so in awe of its orchestral drive, he famously listened to it 100 times a day. With 1963â€™s â€˜Be My Babyâ€™, Phil Spector put a bowtie on the bubblegum love songâ€”conveying loveâ€™s urgency and sweaty-palmed excitement.

34. â€˜The Way You Make Me Feelâ€™ by Michael Jackson

MJâ€™s chart-topping Bad single finds the King of Pop in full-on cupidâ€™s-arrow love-struck mode (contrast with the seedy depictions of romance in the equally compelling â€˜Billie Jeanâ€™ or â€˜Dirty Dianaâ€™). Itâ€™s a plea, in a sense, for love unattainedâ€”but the body-moving, carefree approach leaves little doubt to the singerâ€™s sincerity.

Advertising

35. â€˜Homeâ€™ by Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros

Magnetic Zeros frontpeople Alex Ebert and Jade Castrinos had a whirlwind romance that sparked a band, so itâ€™s only fitting that the Magnetic Zerosâ€™ 2009 breakout hit was this sweet duet. They sing to each other like Johnny Cash and June Carter, with a whole crowd (and a horn section) behind them. What makes this tuneâ€™s aw-shucks, neohippie earnestness work so well is that you can just tell that Ebert and Castrinos mean it. â€˜We laugh until we think weâ€™ll die / Barefoot on a summer night / Never could be sweeter than with you.â€™ This is your soundtrack for cartwheeling through a field of daisies.

36. â€˜Slow Showâ€™ by the National

The National is a band best known for its alternately stately and ravaged examinations of existential dread and anxietyâ€”in short, they're far from lovey-dovey. But this track from their breakout album, 2007's â€˜Boxerâ€™ proves that they're aware of love's curative powers. Frontman Matt Berninger finds himself stranded at a party without his companion and self-deprecatingly details his panic and isolation before identifying the exhilarating recognition of a soulmate with simple precision: â€˜You know I dreamed about you for 29 years before I saw you.â€™

Advertising

37. â€˜Cheek to Cheekâ€™ by Ella Fitzgerald

Untroubled by the darker themes that complicate so many love songs, Irving Berlinâ€™s 1935 classicâ€”written for Fred Astaire to woo Ginger Rogers with, as they dance in the movie Top Hatâ€”is a pure expression of romantic bliss. â€˜Heaven, Iâ€™m in heaven / And my heart beats so that I can hardly speakâ€™: When Ella Fitzgerald sings these lines on her 1958 album of Berlin standards, with a confident and good-natured swing of total contentment, you canâ€™t help joining her in the clouds.

38. â€˜Be My Wifeâ€™ by David Bowie

Although his ultra-melodic Motown thumper â€˜Modern Loveâ€™ is big at weddings, you donâ€™t really go to David Bowie for sincere feelings. But there are exceptions, foremost this astonishing song. Taken from his pioneering electronic opus â€˜Lowâ€™, itâ€™s paradoxically one of Bowie simplest songs: a furiously hammered, almost oompah piano over which he plaintively begs â€˜please be mine, share my life, stay with me, be my wifeâ€™. It is absolutely not a sexy song, but the desperate sound of a man clinging on to a lover like theyâ€™re the last refuge from the storm is itself intensely romantic. Also great if youâ€™re looking for a very literal proposal song.

Advertising

39. â€˜This Must Be the Place (Naive Melody)â€™ by Talking Heads

This 1983 hit was David Byrneâ€™s attempt to write a love song â€˜that wasnâ€™t corny, that didnâ€™t sound stupid or lame the way many do.â€™ Though heâ€™s often avoided the topic (due to it being â€˜kinda big,â€™ as he eloquently puts it), Byrne hit the target here with a sweet, sincere tune about home being wherever your lover is.

40. â€˜Hallelujah I Love Her Soâ€™ by Ray Charles

Ever had a neighbor you canâ€™t stop flirting with? Ray Charles knows the feeling. Of course, the next-door neighbors in his debut single, â€˜Hallelujah I Love Her So,â€™ certainly go beyond being cordial and friendly. Between Don Wilkersonâ€™s tenor sax solo and the sweet lyrics about the quiet kindnesses of romance (bringing coffee to each other, coming at a momentâ€™s phone call) the song captures in its entirety a love that comes from a perfect understanding. When Charles sings that he knows sheâ€™ll be there for him, despite peopleâ€™s doubts, because â€˜she told me so,â€™ it becomes crystal clear that this is the kind of connection thatâ€™s meant to be.

Advertising

41. â€˜The Very Thought of Youâ€™ by Billie Holiday

Originally recorded by Al Bowlly and then Bing Crosby in 1934, Ray Nobleâ€™s jazz standard has been covered time and again this past 80 yearsâ€”but its defining version comes from Lady Day. This 1938 reverie swings like a lazy daydream, Holidayâ€™s voice sweet and languid. â€˜I see your face in every flower,â€™ she coos, reminding you of each time you got lost in fantasy when you were washing the dishes, or watching a movie, or listening to someone explain something to you.â€¦ Sorry, what was that?

42. â€˜Teenage Dreamâ€™ by Katy Perry

Love is rarely as carefree or thrilling as when youâ€™re a teenager, which is why Perryâ€™s 2010 pop stomper never loses its appeal. Whether youâ€™re 25 or 85, thereâ€™s something about the pay-off line â€˜you make me feel like Iâ€™m living a teenage dreamâ€™ that hits hard every single time. When you find that person, donâ€™t let them go.

Advertising

43. â€˜Cherishâ€™ by Madonna

Because we tend to think of her as popâ€™s ultimate envelope-pushing chameleon â€“ something she definitely is â€“ itâ€™s easy to forget that Madonna can also be sweet and tender. This infectious love song from her classic â€˜Like a Prayerâ€™ album is a case in point: â€˜Cherishâ€™ is a charming and heartfelt update of the â€˜60s girl-group sound right down to the perfect loved-up couplet: â€˜Romeo and Juliet / They never felt this way, I bet.â€™

44. â€˜I Wanna Be Your Boyfriendâ€™ by the Ramones

Simply stated, plainly sungâ€”no one can accuse Joey Ramone & Co. of overdoing it. It was drummer Tommy who wrote this ditty, which appeared on the groupâ€™s 1976 debut, and, as far as proposals go, itâ€™d serve as a fine love letter to anyone youâ€™d like to attach yourself to, as long as they arenâ€™t too keen on extended verbiage. This song gets the job done in something like eight lines, a quarter of which are also the title. Short and sweet.

Advertising

45. â€˜I Only Have Eyes for Youâ€™ by The Flamingos

The Flamingosâ€™ 1959 doo-wop classic is a perfect slow-dance standard, with super-literal lyrics about that moment when everything and everyone else fades away. The groupâ€”one in a slew of the â€˜bird groupsâ€™ of the â€™40s and â€™50s, including the Orioles, the Penguins and the Larksâ€”set a high bar for elegant ballads such as this one, and played their own instruments to boot. Swoon.

46. â€˜Eternal Flameâ€™ by the Bangles

The Bangles started out as a Beatles-influenced garage-rock band before gradually becoming glossier and poppier as the â€™80s barrelled on. Co-written and sung by group member Susanna Hoffs, this treacly power ballad topped off with a shameless key change was controversial even within the group. Still, it topped the charts worldwide in 1989 and remains pretty much impossible to resist, thanks largely to Hoffsâ€™ genuinely lovely vocal.

Advertising

47. â€˜Day Dreamingâ€™ by Aretha Franklin

Franklinâ€™s near-flawless 1972 album, â€˜Young, Gifted and Blackâ€™, shifts into this love song with a dreamy jazz flourish before cutting to the legendary singerâ€™s soulful this-is-how-it-is voice. The refrain of â€˜Day Dreamingâ€™ might be all about fantasizing about getting away with your man, but the verses are about trying to change and do everything to be the right woman for him. Though this might seem submissive for a powerful woman, she does say that he â€˜Turns me right on when I hear him say / Hey, baby, let's get away,â€™ so maybe that fantasy is worth it.

48. â€˜At Your Most Beautifulâ€™ by R.E.M.

Since it was released in 1987, many have taken R.E.M.â€™s breakthrough single â€˜The One I Loveâ€™ to be a love song, completely wrongly: itâ€™s actually a brutal dismissal of a former lover. A decade later, though, they penned this absolutely radiant Beach Boys homage, that brims with the uncomplicated magic of being purely in love. Over melodious piano and a lush bed of â€˜doo dooâ€™ backing vocals, Michael Stipeâ€™s breathy, wholesome declaration to his lover that â€˜I found a way to make you smileâ€™ sounds like the most swoonsome thing on earth.

Advertising

49. â€˜Love Hangoverâ€™ by Diana Ross

Before she was coming out and wanting the world to know, Diana first staked a claim on disco by virtue of this supreme 1975 Motown cut. Thanks to a mellow-into-groovinâ€™ tempo change, she lays down the love song law in style by sending away any doctors boasting a cure for her sweet hangover.

50. â€˜Bartenderâ€™ by Lana del Rey

Lana del Reyâ€™s world is, for the most part, one of cynical sex and jaded desires. Which is what makes â€˜Bartenderâ€™ so affecting: itâ€™s a wild but also very touching fantasy of running away from her fame and baggage, buying a vehicle the paps donâ€™t recognise, and starting a simple, pure relationship with a man who appreciates her for who she is. â€˜I bought me a truck in the middle of the night, itâ€™ll buy me a year if I play my cards rightâ€™ she keens. Is the bartender a real guy? Who knows! But itâ€™s her shining, radiant love of freedom that really shines through.

Advertising

51. â€˜You Make My Dreamsâ€™ by Hall & Oates

You donâ€™t even need to listen to the songs lyricsâ€”just that upbeat melodyâ€”to understand that this one is all about that love that makes you want to twirl as soon as you step outside under the sun and skip down a city street.
